Article Title: OpenAI’s startup boss to European companies: Americans are "almost shameless" when ...
Article Text:
FILE - (AP Photo/Michael Dwyer, File)





American startup founders are “almost shameless” in their assertive demands and feedback to AI giant OpenAI , according to Laura Modiano, head of OpenAI’s startups division in EMEA. Speaking at the Sifted Summit this week, Modiano highlighted a stark contrast between U.S. and European entrepreneurs, urging the latter to be more vocal to seize opportunities in the fast-evolving AI landscape. Drawing from her experience working with founders across both regions, Modiano praised American entrepreneurs for their directness.“They come in and say, ‘We need this. You need to improve that,’” she said during a fireside chat. “If founders don’t tell us, we don’t always know.” She encouraged European founders to adopt a similar approach, warning that silence could mean missing out on shaping AI advancements. Modiano pointed to Swedish startup Lovable, valued at $1.8 billion, as a model for effective feedback. The vibe-coding company, which launched its GPT-5-based Lovable Assistant 5 alongside OpenAI’s latest model, provided intensive input during early access. “I was in their office for a week, and every hour we were having reviews,” Modiano recounted, noting that European developers’ feedback directly influenced GPT-5’s development.Another success story is Sana, a Swedish AI-learning platform. Modiano recalled visiting their office, where founders demanded specific voice capabilities, such as tone and speed adjustments. This feedback was cross-referenced with similar requests, leading OpenAI to prioritize those features on its roadmap. “We can only ship what customers tell us they want,” Modiano emphasized, suggesting startups appoint a “chief feedback officer” to ensure their needs are heard.Her comments fuel an ongoing debate about the cultural differences between U.S. and European entrepreneurs. Earlier this year, venture capitalists criticized European founders for lacking the intensity of their American counterparts, with some urging them to adopt a seven-day workweek to compete globally. Harry Stebbings of 20VC previously told CNBC that Europeans often undersell their ambitions, while Americans excel at crafting compelling narratives to pitch their businesses.The critique extends beyond startups. U.K. Business Secretary Peter Kyle recently sparked controversy by claiming British university students lack the entrepreneurial drive of their American peers. Speaking at an Nvidia event in London, Kyle questioned how many U.K. undergraduates attend university with the goal of becoming founders, lamenting a perceived lack of “vigour” in British entrepreneurial culture.Modiano’s call to action is clear: European founders must speak up or risk being left behind in the AI revolution.
Article Summary: Laura Modiano, head of OpenAI’s startups division in EMEA, praised U.S. entrepreneurs for their directness. She urged European founders to adopt a similar approach, warning that silence could mean missing out on AI advancements.

Article Title: FCC on major US websites removing Chinese smartwatches, cameras and other listings: These items could allow…
Article Text:
Representative Image

The removed electronics could allow China to “surveil Americans, disrupt communications networks and otherwise threaten U.S. national security",

“We're going to keep our efforts up,”

How US agencies are putting more restrictions on Chinese technology



Luminous Edge Go 1500 Review: Power, Music & Mobility in One Device

“Covered List,”





The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) chairman, Brendan Carr, has confirmed that major US online retail websites have removed several million listings for prohibited Chinese electronics. In an interview with the news agency Reuters, Carr stated that the removed items were either on a US list of barred equipment or were not authorised by the agency. The electronics included devices such as smartwatches and home security cameras from companies such as Huawei, Hangzhou Hikvision, ZTE, and Dahua Technology. Carr emphasised that the removal is part of an agency-wide crackdown and cited national security as the driving factor.Carr said to Reuters. He noted that, as a result of the FCC's oversight, companies are implementing new processes to prevent prohibited items from being listed in the coming days.The FCC recently issued a new national security notice reminding companies of the ban on certain items, including video surveillance equipment.Carr added.In recent years, US agencies have taken multiple actions against Chinese technology companies across sectors such as telecommunications, semiconductors, and vehicles, citing national security concerns. The latest measure seeks to prevent unapproved Chinese electronics from entering the US market, the Reuters report noted.Earlier this week, the FCC announced plans to vote later this month on strengthening restrictions on telecommunications equipment made by Chinese firms considered national security risks. The move adds to a series of US steps aimed at limiting Beijing’s access to sensitive sectors.The FCC has previously placed companies such as Huawei, ZTE, China Mobile and China Telecom on itswhich prohibits the authorisation of new equipment from those firms.In October, the agency will vote on measures to block approval of devices containing parts from companies on the Covered List and to allow the FCC to restrict the sale of previously authorised equipment in some instances.In March, the FCC said it was investigating nine Chinese companies on the Covered List, including Huawei, ZTE, Hytera Communications (002583.SZ), Dahua Technology (002236.SZ), Pacifica Networks/ComNet, and China Unicom (Americas) (0762.HK).The FCC has earlier barred some Chinese firms from offering telecommunications services in the US, citing national security concerns. Last month, it also began proceedings to withdraw recognition from seven testing laboratories owned or controlled by the Chinese government, citing similar concerns.
Article Summary: Major US online retail websites have removed several million listings for prohibited Chinese electronics. The removed items were either on a US list of barred equipment or were not authorised by the agency. The electronics included devices such as smartwatches and home security cameras from companies such as Huawei, Hangzhou Hikvision, ZTE and Dahua Technology.

Article Text:

“When I grew up, and I saw a video, I could assume that that was a capture of a moment that happened in the real world. What they’re going to … need to think about who is saying it, who’s sharing it, in this case, and what are their incentives, and why might they be saying it,”

Adam Mosseri addresses YouTuber MrBeast ’s AI content creation concern



“scary time”
